advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>German advert for the Philips Odyssey 200 model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dieterkoenig.at/ccc/" target="_blank">Dieter Koening</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRONG WOOMAN(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Don't beleive this advert!<br> Please, look carefully at the quite horizontal shoulders of the woman who carries the Osborne (about 12 Kg). Either she is a champion of wrestling, or the Osborne case is empty. <br><br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COCO CLONE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sampo, a Taiwanese company specialized in monitors and video terminals production also attempted to produce a CoCo clone computer, but the marketing little lasted. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEMS WANTED</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Casio. Basic, it's magic"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> POPULAR ELECTRONICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover and extracts of a 6 page article in the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORANGE+ US AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com" target="_blank">www.textfiles.com</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST SDK-85 AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the Intel logo. Does Intel copies the Apple logo or vice versa?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC.1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEO-GEO ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://spoonman.roarvgm.com/neogeo/" target="_blank">SpoonMan's Neo-Geo page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/">ITSR'S NES ARCHIVE</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #3 (1979) </strong></font><br><blockquote>From Playboy December 1979. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Peathead</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The display says: "Personal computer Pravetz 82"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Yes, it's really him – William Shatner (Captain Kirk).<br> Did they really use VIC-20 in the Enterprise?<br> That would certainly explain a lot of things...<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LUCAS LOGIC BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Maxi Basic Yeno SC 3000 : program at full gallop"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
